Show & tell: thematic maps with R

Intro-presentation

  1. (Dis)advantages of R
  2. Why spatial datavis. in R is become increasingly interesting
    • tidyverse
    • spatial features
    • one workflow for spatial & regular data
  3. Recommended packages for thematic maps
    • tmap
    • ggplot / leaflet / mapview
    • supporting packages
  4. Outline of worked examples / approach
  5. Expectations? Questions?

Setup (optional, if you want run examples during the session)

  • Download and install R.
  • Download and install Rstudio.
  • Download (25MB) and unzip folder with session material (or clone from Github).
  • Open project in Rstudio by clicking “thematic_maps_with_r.Rproj” in unzipped folder.
  • Run commands below to install required R-packages.
install.packages('rmarkdown')
install.packages('sf')
install.packages('tmap')
install.packages('dplyr')
install.packages('readxl')
install.packages('eurostat')
install.packages('leaflet')
install.packages('haven')
install.packages('mapview')
install.packages('rgdal')
install.packages('tmaptools')
install.packages('countrycode')
install.packages('stringr')
install.packages('readr')
install.packages('ggplot2')
install.packages('htmlwidgets')
install.packages('rworldmap')
install.packages('lubridate')

install.packages("BelgiumMaps.StatBel", repos = "http://www.datatailor.be/rcube", type = "source")

R-syntax in a nutshell (enough to follow along)

# Objects, functions, combinations of functions

obj_a <- something            # create/assign something to "object A"
obj_a                         # show object A

obj_b <- do_something(obj_a)  # change object A, creating object B (function)
 
# %>% "pipe" object A through multiple functions, resulting in object B
obj_b <- obj_a %>%
  do_something() %>%
  do_something_else() %>%
  do_another_thing()

# + add things to object A, resulting in object B
obj_b <- obj_a +
  add_something() +
  add_something()
